The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited advertisement
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company template
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.
The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
Egypt 4 July Arcadia 1 August Persia 29 August
Britannia 11 July Marmora 8 August Moldavia 5 Sept.
Caledonia 18 July Arabia 15 August Egypt 12 Sept.
Mongolia 25 July China 22 August Macedonia 19 Sept.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Khedivial Mail Line
KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.
Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

Thos. Cook & Son,
(EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.
RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.
CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.
Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY advertisement
INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.
Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.
Depart. - Cairo 6.35 p.m. Arrival - Alexandria 10.0 p.m.
Depart. - Alexandria 6. 0 p.m. Arrival - Cairo 9.20 p.m.
By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.
Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.
Depart. - Cairo 11 a.m. & 6.15 p.m. Depart. - Port Said 11.55 a.m. & 6.30 p.m.
Arriv. - Ismailia 2.23 p.m. & 9.28 p.m. Arriv. - Ismailia 1.30 p.m. & 8.12 p.m.
Depart. - Ismailia 2.28 p.m. & 9.33 p.m. Depart. - Ismailia 1.35 p.m. & 8.17 p.m.
Arriv. - Port Said 5. 0 p.m. & 11.10 p.m. Arriv. - Cairo 5. 0 p.m. & 11.25 p.m.
Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 1905.
THE VIST OF THE FRENCH FLEET. The official program of the festivities in connection with the visit of the French fleet leaves nothing to be desired. His Majesty the King will review the French Fleet, Admiral Caillard and his gallant and distinguished staff will be his guests, and are specially invited to witness the races for the King’s Cup. Windsor Castle is to be thrown open to our friendly rivals, and we may be sure that our Ruler has still some pleasant surprises in store for his guests. The City of London follows the example of the King ; Portsmouth may be trusted to live up to its reputation, and last but not least, the two Houses will entertain the French officers in Westminster Hall. Six years agp who could have proposed that the centenary year of the Trafalgar would be marked by the fraternisation of the French and British Fleets at Portsmouth following on the friendly visit of a Spanish King to London Yet nothing could be more necessary in the the interests of the peaces of the world, than the “entente cordiale” between two nations whose ideals as to progress and liberty are identical, whose mutual commercial interests increase daily and whose ancient quarrels have become a source of mutual respect. Our soldiers and sailors have not always had the best of the give and take. If the British Fleets swept the seas under Nelson and Collingwood, they were well nigh swept from the seas during the later years of the American war, when Guioben and Suffren commanded victorious squadrons of which any Admiral might have been proud, and though we triumphed under the leadership of the great Iron Duke and the greater Marlborough, the names of Froute noy, Lauffeld, Steinkirk, and neerwinden attest that even the soldiers who swore- and fought- so terribly in Flanders often met their match. Let us,rather, while remembering our victories, forget against whom they were gained and while profiting by out defeats cease to underline in our minds the name of the conqueror. Thus Crecy and Bovines, Hastings and Waterloo, may became names of peaceful omen. We remember a passage in an English novel- alas! the author;s name has escaped us- that bears on this point. Two Englishmen meet in the one guest-room of a tiny hotel in Ireland. Both eye one another over their pipes and one suddenly exclaimed, “Excuse me, but-er-didn’t we meet last behind the fives courts at X…” “Yes,” replies the other, laughing, “and call-over stopped it after the fifth round ;” and the two discuss their old school-days and school quarrels with the greatest good humor in the world. May such be the relations of France and England in the future. They have led a wild and rather quarrelsome youth, they have fought one another out of sheer pugnacity, or out of mutual jealously born of the other’s attentions to various colored enchantresses in Asia and Africa and the Spanish Main, but they are settling down now to a law-abiding and steady middle age. John is ready to admit that Jacques is a right good fellow in spite of his theatrical manner, and Jacques in convinced that John’s reserve hides a warm and friendly heart and both are inclined to think more fondly of Edward the Peacemaker and President Loubet that of William the Conqueror and the Edward who took Calais. Their old war-songs cease to call up memories of battle and Marot;s refrain. “Car France est cimitiere aux Anglsis” and Drayton’s ballad of Agincourt appeal to day to mixed audiences.
THE MARSHALL ISLANDS Australian sensitiveness in connection with German aggressiveness in the Marshall Islands is not likely to be blunted by any tranquilising assurance from minor officials. To give strength and validity to such undertakings,, it is essential that they should come direct from Prince von Bulow. Australians will want to know, therefore, whether the German Consul at Sydney had the Chancellor;s authority for stating that the new laws for the government of the insular group will be framed “in accordance with Australians wishes.” Until about 20 years ago, England and Germany had practically the same footing in the islands. But Downing street, fearing that this dual control might breed future complications, as between England and France in the New Hebrides, gravely affronted Australian sentiment by consenting to the establishment of a German Protectorate. It was strictly covenanted, however, that the than “open door,” should remain open. But Teutonio smartness hit on an expedient to close it. The administrative control, including all fiscal arrangements was handed over to a private commercial concern, the Jaluit Company, which at once proceeded to build up a trading monopoly for its own exclusive profit. One method was the imposition of a duty of L3 per ton on exports in Australian vessels ; but to give this arbitrary act a show of fairness, the same burden was placed on German ship engaged in the business, and so whatsoever sum t disbursed for export duty came back to its treasury as revenue. Australians will wait to see whether Prince von Bulow is of the same mind as this Consular spokesman of his at Sydney.

THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 1905.
THE PEACE COMMISSION.
DELEGATES AT OYSTER BAY.
MR. ROOSEVELTS TOAST
New York, August 5. M. Witte and Baron Rosen paid a visit to President Roosevelt at Oyster Bay, similar to that of Baron Kamoura and M. Takashira last week, with the object of informally eating their respects prior to to-day’s formal reception. It is stated that the question of precedence today has been decided in favor of Japan. (R.)
WASHINGTON, August 5. The plenipotentiaries have arrived at Oyster Bay. The envoys were received by President Roosevelt on board the Government yacht Mayflower. The Japanese preceded the Russians. (Reuter.)
OYSTER BAY, August 5. Mr. Witte handed a letter from the Tsar to Mr. Roosevelt yesterday. Mr. Roosevelt gave a lunch to the Russian and Japanese plenipotentiaries. In his toast he expressed an ardent wish for the conclusion of a just and lasting peace. (Haus.)
WASHINGTON, August 6. President Roosevelt presented the envoys to each other. A luncheon then followed, at which Mr. Roosevelt proposed a toast to the welfare and prosperity of the two great nations, saying that it was his earnest prayer in the interest of all mankind, that a just and last- ing peace may be speedily concluded. The The envoys shook hands cordially when introduced. Before leaving, the Japanese ex- pressed professional gratification at the pleasant meeting. (Reuter.)
CHECK ON RUSSIAN AUTOCRACY
MEETING OF GRAND COUNCIL
ST. PETERSBURG, August 5. Despite the opposition of the reactionary party, the Council of the Empire which met at Peterhof has decided that no bill rejected by a two-thirds majority shall be submitted for the Tsar’s sanction. If the bill be rejected by less that two-thirds majority, reports, both form the majority and minority, will be sub- fitted to the Tsar, who will decide between the two. This decision is important in solving the introduction of the first check on the autocratic power. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, August 3. The Grand Council has decided to accept the project of M. Bouliguine, constitution an assembly of purely consultative representa- tives. (Heaus).
RUSSIAN STRIKES
COSSACKS FIRED ON
ST. PETERSBURG, August 5. It is officially announced that strikers at Novo Rossiak (Cancasia) fired upon a detach- ment of Cossacks, killing one. The Cossacks returned the fire killing 30 and wounding 22. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, August 6. The reservists have been called up for service on the Transcaucasian railways, the employs of which have gone on strike. (H.)
ADVANCE JAPAN:
TOKIO, August 6. The Japanese have introduced a civil admi- mistration at Dalny and Port Arthur. Five thousand Japanese colonists have already arrived at Yingkow. (Reuter.)
SENTENCED TO DEATH:
Moscow, August 5. The assassin of Count Shouvaloff has been condemned to death. (Heaus.)
THE MOROCCO QUESTION
ANOTHER STUMBLING BLOCK
TANGIER, August 5. The French proposals to Germany are regard- ed as exceedingly modest, but though the approval of Germany is considered likely, the objections of the Moorish Court may prove insurmountable. (Reuter.)
THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE.”
FRENCH FLEET AT COWES.
CHERBOURG, August 6. The French fleet has sailed for Cowes, where the King and Queen arrived yesterday evening on the Royal yacht. (Reuter.)
CHERBOURG, 6. The French squadron left for Cowes. (H.)
THE COTTON TRADE
WORKMEN’S DEMANDS REJECTED
LONDON, August 5. The Federation of Cotton Spinners has decided to urge the whole trade to unite in rejecting the workmen’s demand for 5% increase of wages, The Bolton employers have decided to enforce a reduction of 5%
LOCAL AND GENRAL
CHILD EXPOSED.-A new0born child has been found alive in Khatab Street.
HASHISH SEIZED AT CARIO.- 46 tkos of hashish have been seized by the police in the El Gayars road, Esbekiah quarter.
STARY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in Old CArio during to-night and at dawn to- morrow will be poisoned.
SUEZ CANAL - 13 vessels passed through the Canal on the 3rd inst. 8 of which were British, 2 French, 1 Australian, 2 Turkish. The day’s receipts were frs. 345,874,72 making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,045,373 51.
SINAI PENINSULA.- El Miralai Saad Bey Rifat, who is at present “en pension,” has been appointed acting commandant, Sinai Penin- sola, replacing El Kaiwskan Mohamed Bey Kamel, who has been placed in “en disposibilité.”
ARMY BEER CONTRACT.- We understand that Ind, Coope and Co., Limited, of Burton- on-Trent and Romford, have secured the renewal of their contract for the supply of the whole of the troops in Egypt for a further period.
DROWNING FATALITY.- Th body of a native was picked up yesterday by some Araba who saw it floating in the Mahwoudieh Canal and handed it over to the police. It was taken to the hospital, where the inquest appears to have established the fact that death was caused entirely by drowning, there being no suspicion of foul play.
ALHAMBRA THEATER.- Pressure on our space unfortunately compels us to hold over our repot of the excellent opening performance of the Della Guardia Italian dramatic company in Fedora on Saturday. We understand that subscription tickets for 30 performances may be had at P.T. 300. These may be obtained at the box office form the 10th to the 10th inst.
BRAWL IN A CAFE.- The Café Imperial was the scene of a quarrel on Saturday evening which resulted in a tradesman of Jewish origin, who is, we believe, a British subject, receiving three serious stabs between the shoulders with a stiletto, which were inflicted by the nephew of the injured man. Dispute over a game of cards seems to have led to the assault.
THE PLAUGE.- Staurday’s plague bulletin reports the death of a native street-cleaner of Satret el Bahir district of Alexandria, who was found dead at his house. Sunday’s bulletin reports two admissions to hospital and three deaths at Alexandria, and also one death at Port Said. The new cases at Alexandria are those of an Italian grocer of the Chimerly district, and a native street-cleaner of the Echeches Ragheb Pasha. The three cases which ended fatally were all natives, one being the nephew of the second case admitted to hospital yesterday, who was found dead at his home, another was a native workman who had been working in the same shop as the case reported in Saturday, and the third was a native workman found dead at his home in Saladin.
MESSIEURS. WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD. formally inaugurated their reconstructed bar in Old Bourse Palace- which has risen, Phoenix-like, from its ashes- on Saturday even- ing by inviting the members of the local press to a “champagne de press.” The guests had thus an pooprtunity of inspecting the rea;;y magnificent appointments of the bar at their leisure while enjoying a glass of Montebello. The up-to-date manner, and nothing has been overlooked that could ass to the comfort and convenience of clients. The artistic decora- tions, which are usually gorgeous and reflect the greatest credit on the designer, Prof. Kirchmayr, make the establishment one of the most inviting of the kind we have yet seen, The scheme of decoration of the front part of the bar is carried out is “art nounvean,” while the back parlor is a gem of arabesque work, being entirely furnished with masharabieh and bass furniture from Messers. Tara’s workshops. Here, besides enjoying the refreshments supplied, one may read the latest newspapers and magazines in the great- best ease and comfort. Altogether, the place is really worth a visit, and Messers. W. and M. are to be congratulated on affording Alexandria such a pleasant place of meeting, A feature of the establishment is the commissionaries who is an imposing figure of something like 7 feet.

THE SUN’S ECLIPES.
MISSIONS LEAVE FOR ASSOUAN.
The maulers of the British and American astronomical missions which have been sent out in order to observe the forthcoming eclipse of the sun have arrived in Cairo and leave for Assouan this evening, accompanied by Captian Lyons. Captain Lyons will return to Cario on August 31, bu the date of return of the mis- sions is not yet fixed. Another expedition consisting of Russian savants, is due to arrive in Egypt shortly.
On August 30 the moon passes exactly between the sun and our earth, and produces the comparatively rare phenomenon of a total eclipse of the sun.
It is only on such occasions that the corona or halo of light which surrounds the sun, can be seen at all, and it is in consequence of this fact that astronomers journey to distant parts of the earth from which the eclipsed sun can be observed.
For European observers the line of totality of the approaching eclipse is very conveniently placed, so that it can be reached quiet easily and at a small expense. The elliptical shadow of the moon on the earth’s surface moves from Hudson’s Bay to Arabia, so that the path traced out is considerable length, but only about 120 miles broad.
To observe the corona, therefore it is neces- say to place oneself somewhere on this small strip of the the earth’s surface. After leaving the American continent at Labrador, the shadow sweeps across the Atlantic and strikes Europe near Cape Ortega, in the north-west of Spain, passes over Spanish territory, convenient towns traversed being Oviedo, Valencia, Bur- dos, Ateca, Calatayud, and Castellón. The shadow then crosses the Mediterranean, pass- ing over the islands of Majoroa and Ivisa and cuts the African continent near Philippeville and Callo, in Algeria. in its eastward course it falls on Sfax in Tunia, and numerous coast stated in Tripoli, and towards the end of its career passes over Egypt near Assouan, and finally terminates in Arabia.
the facts that the eclipse occurs in the month of Augustm when many people can afford the time to visit Southern Europe, that the track is comparatively near home, that totality last for over three minutes, and fi- nally that this is the only total solar eclipse that can be easily reaches from England for some years to come, account for the great popular interest attached to this event.
Astronomers have been making very exten- sive preparations for securing as many photo- graphs and observations as possible, and, according to present arrangements they are about to take up their stations along this narrow line.
The names of the astronomers who are leaving for Assouan this evening are Mr. Keeling, mr. Joy, Dr. West, Mr. Ballamy Professor H. Turner, and Dr. and Mrs. Hausey.
EGYPTIAN ARMY.
Leave of absence has been granted to the following officials of the Sudan Government and Army officers until the undermentioned dates:-
El Kaimakam Herbert Bey, Assistant Adju- cant General, Recruiting, until November 1; El Kaimakam Pearson Bey. Director of Sur- vets, until September 18; EL Bimbashi Das -sey-Browning, Medical Corps, until October 15; El Bimbasbi Potter, 16th Battalion, until October 19; EL Kaimaskam Wood Bey, officer commanding 2nd Battalion and EL Bimbasbi Ryan. Lieut. E. st. G. Loather, Royal Artillery who arrived in Egypt on the 14th of last month, is taken in the strength of the Egypt- ian Army with the rank of Bimbashi and is posted to the Artillery.
NILE GAUGE READINGS.
The non-arrival of the gauge readings from Rosaries since the 20th of the last month is due to the fact that the telegraph office has been closed on account of the illness of th clerk. On Saturday last the office was still closed but the irrigation inspector telegraphed the missing reading of the last month from Slings, a station some thirty miles from Rosaries and we are now able to complete our July table.
We can easily understand the inconvenience which would be caused by the illness of a telegraph clerk in such a remote district and the difficulty of replacing him at a moment’s notice, but the Telegraph Administration must have now been aware of the fact for about a fortnight. It is a very serious matter to deprive the public of telegraphic communica- tion to any station for even the shortest period but when a telegraph office is closed for more than a fortnight, merely on account of a clerk’s illness, it would seem that the authorities show a considerable disregard for the public which takes some interest in the Nile flood.

AN IMPORTANT DISCOVERY.
HIDDEN TREASURE AT
TOUKH EL GARAMOUS.
A Tell or mound, close to the village of Touch el Garamous, in the Facous district, has yielded a magnificent treasure to the Antiquities Service. It appears that a few months agate Government authorised a rich proprietor of the neighbourhood to take sebakh from the mound and with that object gangs if villagers not to work to dig outtings into the Tell, which rises some 10 metres above the surrounding lines, and a Deauville railways was constructed to remove the loads of sebakh as fast as they were dug out.
The Government had prudently inserted a clause in the contract insisting on all the necessary precautions being taken to protect an antiquities that might be discovered during the digging, and the Antiquities Ser- vice posted a ghaffir on the spot who was charge to protect its interests. In August 3 the ghaffir was riding over the Tell on a donkey, when the beast suddenly came down heavily. The rider after picking himself up, found that one of the ass’s forelegs had gone through the roof of a vault. He enlarged the opening and saw a treasure; two or three watchers rushed to the spot, the village follow- ed in a body, and the nearest omdeh was sent for.
Lord Cromer, in his report for 1904 re- marks that causes have come before him in which omdehs have shown the most praise- worthy tact and presence of mind. The omdeh of Toukh el Garamous Ahmad Effendi And ed Ali, appears to have possessed the ;after virtue in a high degree. Finding the gaffer executing the villagers of desiring to steal the objects in the vault and the villagers accusing the gaffer of having already stolen most of them the omdeh kept the crowd away called up the sheikhs and ordered them to guard the vault for the night wired to the Antiquities Service and the Momour of th earkas and though we cannot guarantee the last item, put the ghaffir under observation. He then took an inventory of the objects discovered.
On the evening of the 3rd inst. the native Inspector of the Antiquities Service came up from Faoour. The Inspector from Zagazig followed next day, and the treasure about which the energetic omdah and the sheik had camped all nights put under guard Saab, according to out informants, are the de- tails of this most interesting discovery. If the list of the objects discovered, which we have received is substantially accurate it is obvious that a find of the highest impor- dance and value has been made.
Here are some of the principle objects which have been inventoried- 2 silver bowls. one of them gilt, 2 candlesticks, a silver crown a silver figure of a cock, part of the head of a silver statuette covered with gold lead, a pair of gold polished bracelets with the clapse carved in the shape of a bird with a housing face, a bracelet with the figure of Horus on the catch a gold bracelet shaped like a serpents with a red stone set in the head, a golden diadem set with jewels, nine plates of silver a chased silver bowl, 17 silver and 118 gold coins, th leather bearing either the head of monarch, or the figures of a bird, etc. etc.
We imagine from the appearance of the coins is this list that the treasure will prove to be Roman or Psolemaic. Owing to the absence of all its European inspectors the Antiquities Service at Cario has been unable to furnish us with any information on the subject.
ENGLISH MISSION TO JERUSALEM
Arrangements are now almost completed for the pilgrimage of members of the English Church Union to the Holy lean, and the departure has been fixed for Nov. 3. The Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, Dr .Blyth will travel with the party, and it is proposed to hold services, at Nazareth on Nov. 14. On Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Nov. 20, 21, and 22 there will be special celebrations of the Eucharist in the Chapel of Abraham in the Church of the Holy Sepultures the Patriarch of Jerusalem having given the requisite per- mission

NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
A REMARKABLE TOW.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT )
Port Said, Sunday.
We had here yesterday a large tug, the Oceans on her return voyage from Saborg in Sumatra. This vessel on the 9th May was sighted coming in from the sea, having in tow a large vessel evidently much larger than herself. The Oceans of 115 tons net, and her consort the Tankerville whose tonnage was 2320 had come out form Eastern Europe in 17 days, and although the monsoon is blowing all the time in the Arabian sea, they proceeded and eventually arrived in safety. This tow, both for its length (over 8000 miles) and its freedom form serious accident is well worthy of note. I was informed that all went well on the voyage the tug coaling form her tow as occasions demanded and that but little occurred to mar the success of what is one of the greatest tows with have been made for some years. THE Tankerskille is an oil vessel intended for the carriage of petroleum on the Sumatra coast.
THE MATIANA.
The Matiana (which vessel went badly ashore on Friday and completely blocked all traffic for some time) is now anchor in Lake Tim- san (Ismailia ) undergoing repairs to her steering gear, a defect in which was the cause of the accident, She will probably leave on Monday.
HARBOR IMPROVEMENTS
A tremendous amount of work in being done on downs Poiut in anticipation of the con- striation of stored and warehouses. Roads are being altered stretches of land leveled and quantities of sand are being removed to the Lake ashore near the spot where in the near future will be built the MAtarieh canal terminus
The “Chantier des Bloca” has also been much altered half being cut away and walls having been built to protect the banks of what is intended to bed in the future the danger anborges The eastern side of the aneborge approach will be protected by a stone breakwater a large portion of which is already completed. The bathing house are I believe to be pulled down at the end of the summer and the site noe occupied by them is to be dredged to a depth of 8 metres This will permit of dredgers hoppers and craft of a like nature all going into their berths and maneuvering quite clear of all the sea-going traffic instead of as at permit using the main channels and frequently greatly disturb- ing the harbour traffic.
NOTES FROM SUEZ
RUSSIAN HOSPITAL SHIP
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
The Russian hospital ship Kostroma belong- ing to the 3rd division of Admiral Rodjetveien keys squadron is expected to arrive ar Suez shortly from Shanghai with wounded on board It will be remembered that this ship was cap- turred by the Japanese during the great navel battle and taken to Sasebom owing it was alleged to her having infringed he Hagues Conventions The Kostroms was subsequently released.
THE MATIANA
The B.I. steamer Matiana which grounded in the Canal yesterday forenoon came off without assistance in the afternoon at 4 o clock and proceeded to Imaillis where she will remain a day or two owing to a breakdown in her sheering gear.
SMALL DANCE
Last Friday evening a number of the members of the Cercie International at Port Tewik arranged a dance in honor of the captain and officers of the ETC cable ship Elector which is leaving Suez next Tuesday morning on her way home. She will be relieved by the Duplex due at Port Said on or about Wednesday Dancing was kept up to alate hour and was attended by a large number of the European residents of Suez and Port Tweak

SPORT AND PLAY
CRICKET
London, August 5 Kent beat Surret by ten wickets. Jetta Gloucestershire and Yorkshire Hampshire were abandoned. The rest of the matches for this date were drawn.
A.C.C ROYAL BERKSHIRE REGIMENT Played on Saturday last. The regiment won the toss and sent in Capt. Moore and Mr. Strange who made a fair start putting on 23, when the former fell to a fast ball from Maclarei. A collapse followed six wickets going down for 39, and though Capt. Binglay and Pta. Webb added a few by hitting out, that total for the innings was only 13. H.B. Carver was the most successful of the Club bowlers. With an easy task before them, the A.C.C. bataman treated the regi- ment’s bowling with a great want of respect, and after Maclaren had left at 16, H.B. Carver and Stacey did what they pleased till the score reached 175, when Carver, in getting back to hook a lob, trod on his wicket. His innings of 101 was marked by great vigour and brilliancy and he gave no chances till he had made 78, when he might have been caught twice and stumped once. Macaulay who came in next, hit extremely freely all round the wicket and was not out when stumps were drawn, with a vigorous 77 to his credit. Stacey, who played with more freedom than usual, carried out his bat for a chanceless 87 the club thus winning easily and decisively. Score-
